item.title: China’s Warning on Blind-Box Toys Sends Pop Mart Shares Sliding
item.description: Pop Mart International Group Ltd. shares dropped in Hong Kong after a Chinese state media commentary called for stricter regulation of blind-box toys and trading cards. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Gain, Dollar Falls as Trump Mulls Iran Role: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian equities rose and the dollar declined, after the White House said President Donald Trump would decide within two weeks whether Washington will join Israel in launching strikes against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

item.title: MSCI Signals South Korea Has More Work to Do to Win an Upgrade
item.description: Global index provider MSCI Inc. signaled that South Korea’s bid to secure an upgrade to developed-market status continues to face several impediments, even as it lauded efforts by the nation’s authorities to improve market access and implement currency reforms.
item.dc:creator: Youkyung Lee

item.title: Lower Gas Prices to Spur Record July Fourth Road Trips, AAA Says
item.description: A record number of US drivers are expected to hit the road for the July Fourth holiday period starting next weekend, helped by the cheapest gasoline in four years.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Cartier

media:content.media:description: A customer refuels at a gas station in Dallas, Texas. Photographer: Shelby Tauber/Bloomberg

item.title: Sanchez Is Putting NATO’s Trump Plan at Risk by Opposing 5% Goal
item.description: The problems piling up for Primer Minister Pedro Sanchez in Spain are threatening to spill into next week’s NATO summit, with potentially drastic consequences for the rest of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

item.title: Tencent Music Shares Double on Break From China Price Cut Script
item.description: China tech investors weary of the nation’s relentless price competition can look to one pocket that’s thriving by moving in the opposite direction: online music.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

item.title: Fidelity Fund Bets on Midcaps Saying Tariff Shock Is Over
item.description: Financial markets have seen the worst of Donald Trump’s tariff threats, helping make midcap stocks an attractive buy as the outlook improves, according to a Fidelity International money manager.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson

item.title: Oil Could Spike to $90 If Strait of Hormuz Shut, Citigroup Says
item.description: Brent crude could jump to around $90 a barrel if the Strait of Hormuz is closed, according to Citigroup Inc., which added that a prolonged halt to shipping through the crucial waterway would be unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker cruises towards the Strait of Hormuz.

item.title: Temu US Sales Plunge 25% as Amazon Rival Shifts Focus Elsewhere
item.description: Temu’s sales decline in the US is deepening as the online marketplace drastically cuts spending on advertising targeting American consumers, signaling a shift in focus after President Donald Trump’s tariff barrage.
item.dc:creator: Jinshan Hong, Daniela Wei

item.title: China’s Warning on Blind-Box Toys Sends Pop Mart Shares Sliding
item.description: Pop Mart International Group Ltd. shares dropped in Hong Kong after a Chinese state media commentary called for stricter regulation of blind-box toys and trading cards, stoking concern over the company’s wildly popular Labubu dolls business.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Labubu dolls at a Pop Mart store in Shanghai. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

item.title: New World’s Bond Prices Surge as It Nears Refinancing Deal
item.description: New World Development Co.’s dollar bonds are poised to hit their highest levels this month as the company closes in on a crucial loan refinancing deal.
item.dc:creator: Pearl Liu, Trista Xinyi Luo, Apple Ka Ying Li

media:content.media:description: Prospective buyers look at a model of the Deep Water Pavilia project, developed by New World Development Co., in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: Philippines to Step In Should Peso Weakness Threaten Prices
item.description: Philippine central bank Governor Eli Remolona said authorities are prepared to intervene more strongly in the foreign-exchange market should the decline in the peso threaten inflation.
item.dc:creator: Ditas B Lopez, Neil Jerome Morales

item.title: Morgan Stanley Says Hong Kong’s Housing Sector Is Bottoming Out
item.description: Hong Kong’s residential property market is poised for a recovery after enduring a seven-year downturn, according to Morgan Stanley.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Kwan

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings developed by New World Development Co. under construction in the Kai Tak area of Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Set for First Weekly Drop in Three as Haven Demand Softens
item.description: Gold headed for its first weekly drop in three, as a slight easing of geopolitical tensions in the Middle East sapped haven demand and a Federal Reserve inflation warning raised the prospect of fewer rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: It’s Raining Deals, But no Signs of Market Euphoria in India
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Oil Drops as Trump Signals Iran Strike Decision Within Two Weeks
item.description: Oil slumped after President Donald Trump signaled a decision on whether to strike Iran will be made within two weeks, easing fears about an imminent attack from the US.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Oil tankers. Photographer: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai Leader’s Fate Hangs in Balance as Allies Weigh Future
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's fate remains uncertain after opposition calls and street protests for her to resign following a leaked phone call in which she criticized her army. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Societe Generale's Benzimra on Outlook for Asian Stocks
item.description: Societe Generale's Frank Benzimra shares his views on the South Korean, Chinese and Southeast Asian stock markets. He says the firm is looking at the China consumption story, and adds that it's neutral on India and underweight Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand. Benzimra speaks on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Imax China CEO on Tariffs, Ne Zha 2 Impact
item.description: Imax China is aggressively adding screens across the country, betting on big local and US productions to boost its sales. Partner Wanda Film, China’s largest movie exhibitor, is planning to replace 27 premium format screens with Imax’s larger high-tech jumbo screens. In a wide-ranging conversation, Bloomberg's Stephen Engle discusses the impact of the trade war and Ne Zha 2 with CEO Daniel Manwaring. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: TSMC Shares Trail Smaller Peer UMC After High-Dividend ETF Snub
item.description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.’s stock is lagging smaller rival United Microelectronics Corp. after being brushed aside by some of Taiwan’s biggest yield-focused exchange-traded funds.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Wang

item.title: China Youths Find Hope in Spiritual Healing
item.description: Tarot readings, bazi consultations, and crystal healing are booming in China as disillusioned youth seek hope amid a sluggish job market and falling wages. In Beijing, bars and cafés now pair coffee or whiskey with fortune-telling sessions. The pan-mental health market is projected to reach $1.5 billion next year, according to Frost & Sullivan. But the rise of this “superstition economy” is drawing scrutiny from authorities, Bloomberg's Minmin Low reports from Beijing. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Evergrande Tycoon’s Ex-Wife Spent Millions on Homes as Firm Sank
item.description: The ex-wife of China Evergrande Group’s chairman spent millions on luxury apartments in London, nine months after the developer defaulted on its loans.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng, Max Harlow

media:content.media:description: The Thames City residential development in London. Google Maps

item.title: JD.com Billionaire’s Viral Stunt Reignites China’s Food-Delivery Feud
item.description: One unusually warm evening in April, Richard Liu revved his scooter through Beijing’s traffic-snarled streets alongside other delivery workers, and then personally handed food orders to surprised customers. Later that night, over spicy hotpot and ice-cold beer, the JD.com Inc. founder welcomed a pair of riders from two rival delivery firms to his company.
item.dc:creator: Luz Ding, Zheping Huang, Claire Che

item.title: Rural Bank Plans Return to Japan Bonds After Winning on Nvidia
item.description: A Japanese regional bank that has stood out among its peers for making money on assets ranging from US Treasuries to Nvidia Corp. is now looking closer to home for investments.
item.dc:creator: Taiga Uranaka

media:content.media:description: The Iyogin Holdings headquarters building in Matsuyama. Photographer: Taiga Uranaka/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Stocks Still Under Shadow of BOJ Unwinding Bond Holdings
item.description: The Bank of Japan is fine-tuning its pullback from the bond market but this mustn’t obscure the fact that quantitative tightening is well underway and likely to cause instability in some stocks.
item.dc:creator: Hideyuki Sano

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged and unveiled a plan to slow its withdrawal from the bond market from next year in a sign of caution following heightened market volatility.

item.title: Canada Moves to Protect Steel and Aluminum Firms, Considers Higher Tariffs
item.description: Canada has opened the door to increasing its tariffs on US steel and aluminum next month if trade talks with the Trump administration stall.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight, Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's incoming prime minister, speaks at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco steel facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister within days.

item.title: Australian Funds Cut US Treasury Holdings on Trump Policy Risks
item.description: A number of Australia’s biggest investors say they are cutting their holdings of US Treasuries, citing concern over President Donald Trump’s tariff and tax plans.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson, Amy Bainbridge

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The US Treasury has $144 billion of extraordinary measures left, in addition to its cash pile, to help keep paying the government's bills, the department said, citing data as of June 11.

item.title: US Futures Drop as Trump Weighs Strikes on Iran: Markets Wrap
item.description: Oil trimmed earlier gains and equity futures remained lower after White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said President Trump will decide within two weeks whether to back Israel militarily in its conflict with Iran. The remarks offered some short-term clarity but did little to resolve broader uncertainty around potential US involvement and the risk of renewed energy-driven inflation.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy.

item.title: Gold Holds as Traders Weigh Inflation Warning, Middle East Risks
item.description: Gold traded little changed as investors weighed rising geopolitical risks in the Middle East against an inflation warning from the Federal Reserve that raises the possibility of fewer US rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: First Quantum Takes Small Steps in Long Road to Panama Mine Restart
item.description: First Quantum Minerals Ltd. is receiving some encouraging signs for its shuttered mine in Panama, though the nation’s president warned there’s a long way to go before reaching a deal to restart.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood, Michael D McDonald
